qas.question: What does the abbreviation STOIC stand for?
When was Imperial College Union's TV station founded?
Where was a cable link located that connected the Southside Halls of residence?
When was the station renamed to it's modern name?
When was the college radio station founded?

plausible_answers.text: a small TV studio in the Electrical Engineering block.

qas.question: Where is the radio station operated from?

plausible_answers.text: moving the VTR and a monitor into a common room

qas.question: How where news programs played for staff?
When was a cable link added to the dorms?
When did the society change its name from ICTV

context:
<a1_0>Imperial College TV<a1_0/>
ICTV (formerly STOIC (<a0_0>Student Television of Imperial College<a0_0/>)) is Imperial College Union's TV station, founded in <a2_0><b5_0>1969<b5_0/><a2_0/> and operated from <b6_0>a small TV studio in the Electrical Engineering block.<b6_0/> The department had bought an early AMPEX Type A 1-inch videotape recorder and this was used to produce an occasional short news programme which was then played to students by simply <b7_0>moving the VTR and a monitor into a common room<b7_0/>. A cable link to the Southside halls of residence was laid in a tunnel under <a3_0>Exhibition Road<a3_0/> in <b8_0>1972<b8_0/>. Besides the news, early productions included a film of the Queen opening what was then called College Block and interview programmes with DJ Mike Raven, Richard O'Brian and Monty Python producer Ian MacNaughton. The society was renamed to ICTV for the <a4_0>start of the <b9_0>2014/15 academic year<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
